item.title: [HBASE-9482] Do not enforce secure Hadoop for secure HBase
item.description:
We should recommend and not enforce secure Hadoop underneath as a requirement to run secure HBase.

Few of our customers have HBase clusters which expose only HBase services to outside the physical network and no other services (including ssh) are accessible from outside of such cluster.

However they are forced to setup secure Hadoop and incur the penalty of security overhead at filesystem layer even if they do not need to.

The following code tests for both secure HBase and secure Hadoop.

org.apache.hadoop.hbase.security.User

  /**

   * Returns whether or not secure authentication is enabled for HBase.  Note that

   * HBase security requires HDFS security to provide any guarantees, so this requires that

   * both <code>hbase.security.authentication</code> and <code>hadoop.security.authentication</code>

   * are set to <code>kerberos</code>.

   */

  public static boolean isHBaseSecurityEnabled(Configuration conf) {

    return "kerberos".equalsIgnoreCase(conf.get(HBASE_SECURITY_CONF_KEY)) &&

        "kerberos".equalsIgnoreCase(

            conf.get(CommonConfigurationKeys.HADOOP_SECURITY_AUTHENTICATION));

  }

What is worse that if "hadoop.security.authentication" is not set to "kerberos" (undocumented at http://hbase.apache.org/book/security.html), all other configuration have no impact and HBase RPCs silently switch back to unsecured mode.

+1 from me

-    return "kerberos".equalsIgnoreCase(conf.get(HBASE_SECURITY_CONF_KEY)) &&

-        "kerberos".equalsIgnoreCase(

-            conf.get(CommonConfigurationKeys.HADOOP_SECURITY_AUTHENTICATION));

+    String authScheme = conf.get(HBASE_SECURITY_CONF_KEY);

+    return ! (authScheme == null

+              || authScheme.length() == 0

+              || "simple".equalsIgnoreCase(authScheme));

Why this change instead of just dropping the check against HADOOP_SECURITY_AUTHENTICATION? Previous behavior was the value must be "kerberos" for strong authentication. New behavior would be anything except "simple" results in strong authentication being configured (whether or not it works). Would this be expected?

stack: Would add that shortly.

Gary Helmling: I did that so that in future if another strong authentication is supported in a configurable way, this [isHBaseSecurityEnabled()] need not change. Since today, the only options are simple or kerberos, it should not have any real behavior change.

Aditya Kishore It effectively changes the fallback for a misconfiguration from "simple" to "kerberos". I don't think this is an area that makes sense to future proof until other security implementations are available. It's not clear that places where User.isHBaseSecurityEnabled() is currently used would be able to transparently make use of different authentication methods anyway. I think the previous explicit check for "kerberos" is clearer.
To be clear, I'm okay with the change in concept, but I'd prefer to not make this change in behavior.
Understood, will update the patch shortly.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue:
While it is possible to run secure HBase without securing underlying filesystem, it is recommended that you run secure HBase on top of a secured HDFS cluster to provide stronger guarantees of security. In such cases, you must configure HBase services to be able to authenticate to HDFS services.

However, if the cluster hosting HBase service is protected via other means; for example if it exports only HBase services to external users; you may save some overhead by running secure HBase over unsecured HDFS. In such cases, you must ensure that the HDSF services are not accessible to external user via any means.
